message.content: This question requires a basic understanding of the sources of air pollution. Option (C) is the most likely answer because pollution in the air is often caused by human activities, such as emissions from factories or vehicles. Option (A) is incorrect because air pollution does not develop on its own. Option (B) is also incorrect because while a hurricane can have some localized effects on air quality, it is not the usual cause of widespread air pollution. Option (D) is unlikely to be the main cause of air pollution, as the emissions from a flock of birds would not be significant enough to cause significant pollution on a larger scale.

This question requires an understanding of the sources of air pollution. While air pollution can occur naturally in some cases (such as volcanic eruptions or forest fires), the most common and significant source of air pollution is human activity, specifically actions by businesses and industries. These can include emissions from factories, power plants, vehicles, and other activities that release pollutants into the air. Option (A) is incorrect because air pollution does not develop on its own. Option (B) is also incorrect because while a hurricane can cause damage and destruction, it is not a significant source of air pollution. Option (D) is incorrect because while bird droppings can contribute to pollution in localized areas, it is not a major cause of air pollution on a broader scale.

To answer this question, we need some knowledge about the main causes of air pollution. Option (C) states that an action by a business is more likely to have caused pollution in the air. This is correct because various human activities, such as industrial processes, vehicle emissions, and power generation, are major contributors to air pollution. Option (A) is incorrect because air pollution does not develop on its own. Option (B) is unlikely as hurricanes do not directly cause air pollution. Option (D) is also unlikely as a flock of birds would not have a significant impact on air pollution compared to human activities.

This question asks about the most likely cause of pollution in the air. Option (C) states that an action by a business is more likely to have caused pollution. This can be inferred from the fact that businesses often engage in activities that release pollutants into the air, such as factories emitting smoke or vehicles emitting exhaust fumes. Option (A) is incorrect because pollution does not develop on its own, it is caused by human or natural activities. Option (B) is unlikely to be a major source of pollution in the air, as hurricanes typically disperse pollutants rather than create them. Option (D) is also unlikely to be a significant cause of pollution, as the amount of pollution caused by a flock of birds would be negligible compared to other sources.
